categories.subtitle: Basic/commonly used
categories.explanation: These are the most basic and frequently used Git commands for adding files, committing changes, checking out branches, pushing to remote repositories, pulling from remote repositories, and checking the current status of the repository.

ga: Used before committing to specify which files to include in the commit.

gcmsg: The -m option allows you to provide the commit message directly.

gco: Switches between branches or restores files.
Use it to move between different branches or restore files to an earlier state.

gp: Pushes local commits to the remote repository.
Sends committed changes from the local repository to the remote.

gl: Fetches and merges changes from the remote repository.
Updates the local branch with changes from the corresponding remote branch.

gst: Displays the status of the working directory and staging area.
Shows which changes are staged, unstaged, or untracked.

categories.subtitle: Staging changes
categories.explanation: Staging is the process of adding your changes to the staging area before committing them. These commands help you stage files selectively, stage all changes, or handle changes in patches for review before committing.

ga: Add specified files or changes to the staging area.

gaa: Stages all modified, new, or deleted files in the working directory.

gapa: Allows you to review and stage specific parts of a file in patches.

gav: Displays detailed information during the staging process.

categories.subtitle: Committing changes
categories.explanation: Once changes are staged, they can be committed to the local repository. These commands cover basic commit operations, amend previous commits, and sign commits for security verification.

gc: Creates a new commit from staged changes and shows details of the commit.

gc!: Modify the last commit with additional changes or a new message.

gca: Automatically stages and commits all modified and deleted tracked files.

gcas: Commits all changes and adds a sign-off.
Includes a 'Signed-off-by' line in the commit message, often used in open-source projects.

categories.subtitle: Branch management
categories.explanation: Branches allow you to work on different features or bug fixes simultaneously. These commands help create, delete, list, and manage local and remote branches.

gb: Shows the current branches or creates a new one.

gbd: Deletes a local branch that has been fully merged.

gcb: Creates and switches to a new branch.
Creates a new branch and switches to it immediately.

gbr: Displays all the branches available in the remote repository.

categories.subtitle: Switching branches
categories.explanation: Switching between branches is a core Git feature, allowing you to move between different code states or features easily. These commands help you switch to an existing branch or create a new branch on the fly.

gco: Switch to an existing branch or restore files.

gcb: Creates and switches to a new branch.
Immediately creates and moves to a new branch.

gsw: A simpler alternative to checkout, used for switching branches.

gswc: Creates and switches to a new branch.

categories.subtitle: Syncing with remote
categories.explanation: Git repositories are often hosted remotely. These commands are used to fetch the latest changes from the remote repository, pull changes into your local branch, and push your changes to the remote.

gf: Downloads commits, files, and refs from a remote repository.
Fetches updates from the remote repository without merging them.

gfo: Fetches updates from the origin remote.
Gets the latest changes from the default remote repository.

gl: Fetches and merges updates from the remote repository.
Combines fetch and merge to update the local branch.

gp: Pushes local commits to the remote repository.
Sends the committed changes to the remote repository.

categories.subtitle: Viewing commit logs
categories.explanation: Commit logs provide a history of the changes made to the repository. These commands allow you to view logs in different formats, including a simple list of commits or a graph view showing branching and merging.

glog: Shows a simplified view of commit history.

glg: Shows commit history with file changes.
Provides a summary of changes made in each commit.

glgg: Displays commit history as a graph.
Shows the commit history as a graphical representation of branching and merging.

glo: Adds branch and tag names to the compact commit log.

categories.subtitle: Merging changes
categories.explanation: Merging is the process of integrating changes from one branch into another. These commands help merge branches, handle merge conflicts, and use external tools to assist with merge conflict resolution.

gm: Merges changes from one branch into another.
Integrates the changes from one branch into your current branch.

gmom: Merges the main branch from the origin remote.
Brings changes from the main branch on the remote into the current branch.

gmum: Combines changes from the main branch of an upstream repository.

gma: Cancels the ongoing merge and resets the state to before the merge started.

categories.subtitle: Conflict resolution
categories.explanation: Merge or rebase conflicts happen when Git cannot automatically resolve changes between branches. These commands help open merge tools, abort a merge or rebase, or manually resolve conflicts.

gmtl: Opens the merge tool to resolve conflicts.
Launches the configured merge tool to resolve conflicts.

gmtlvim: Opens Vimdiff as the merge tool.
Uses Vimdiff to help resolve merge conflicts interactively.

gma: Cancels an ongoing merge and resets the repository to its state before the merge.

grba: Stops and undoes any changes from the rebase, restoring the pre-rebase state.

categories.subtitle: Tagging and cleaning
categories.explanation: Tags are used to mark specific commits, often for release versions. Cleaning the working directory helps remove untracked files. These commands help you create, list, and sort tags, as well as clean the repository.

gts: Tags the current commit with a cryptographic signature for release or reference.

gtv: Displays all tags, sorted in a way that respects versioning.

gclean: Interactively removes untracked files from the working directory.

gpristine: Hard resets the repository and removes all untracked files, effectively making it 'pristine'.

categories.subtitle: Stash management
categories.explanation: Stashing temporarily saves changes that are not ready to be committed, so you can switch branches or pull updates without losing work. These commands help stash, list, apply, or drop stashes.

gsta: Saves current changes to the stash.
Temporarily stores your uncommitted changes so you can work on something else.

gstaa: Re-applies the stashed changes to the working directory without deleting them from the stash.

gstl: Displays all the changes you've stashed so far.

gstp: Applies and removes the latest stash.
Re-applies the stashed changes to the working directory and removes them from the stash list.

categories.subtitle: Remote management
categories.explanation: Managing remotes allows you to configure and control the repositories hosted on different servers. These commands help you add, remove, rename, and update remotes.

gr: Shows existing remote connections or adds, renames, or removes remotes.

gra: Associates a new remote repository with the local repository.

grrm: Deletes the connection to a remote repository.

grmv: Changes the name of an existing remote repository.

categories.subtitle: Reverting and resetting
categories.explanation: Reverting undoes specific commits, while resetting moves the HEAD and optionally the working directory to a previous state. These commands help you undo commits or reset the repository to an earlier point.

grev: Creates a new commit that undoes the changes introduced by a previous commit.

grh: Resets the current HEAD to a specific state.
Moves the HEAD pointer to a specified commit, optionally modifying the working directory and staging area.

grhh: Resets both the working directory and index to a previous state, discarding all changes.

groh: Hard resets the current branch to match the remote.
Forces the local branch to exactly match the remote branch, discarding local changes.

categories.subtitle: Viewing changes
categories.explanation: Viewing changes helps track the differences between your working directory, staged files, and the last commit. These commands help you view diffs, cached changes, and differences between branches.

gd: Displays changes between your working directory and the index or a commit.

gdca: Displays the changes that have been staged but not yet committed.

gds: A synonym for `--cached` to view staged changes before committing.

gdup: Shows differences with the upstream branch.
Displays the differences between your local branch and its remote upstream counterpart.

categories.subtitle: Applying patches
categories.explanation: Patches allow you to apply changes from another repository or from a diff file. These commands help you apply patches and handle conflicts when necessary.

gap: Applies changes from a patch file to the current working directory.

gapt: Applies a patch with three-way merge.
Attempts to apply a patch while automatically resolving conflicts using three-way merge.

categories.subtitle: Help and config
categories.explanation: These commands provide assistance and display configuration settings in Git. The help command gives access to Gitâ€™s built-in documentation, while the config command shows or modifies repository settings.

ghh: Opens the help documentation for Git commands.

gcf: Displays all the configuration variables set in the repository or globally.

categories.subtitle: Submodule management
categories.explanation: Submodules allow you to include other Git repositories within a project. These commands help clone repositories with submodules, initialize, and update submodules.

gcl: Clones a repository and its submodules.
Clones a repository and initializes all its submodules automatically.

gsu: Fetches and checks out the latest changes for all submodules.

gsi: Prepares submodules to be fetched and checked out.

categories.subtitle: Interactive commands
categories.explanation: These commands open interactive Git tools, including the Git GUI and GitK, which provide a graphical interface to handle Git operations visually.

gg: Launches the Git GUI for committing, reviewing, and managing repository changes visually.

gga: Opens the Git GUI for amending.
Allows you to amend the last commit using the Git GUI.

gk: Launches GitK to display a graphical history of all branches and commits.

categories.subtitle: SVN support
categories.explanation: For projects that use both Git and SVN, these commands help manage SVN integration, allowing you to commit and rebase changes between the two version control systems.

gsd: Submits your local changes back to the SVN repository.

gsr: Updates your local Git repository with the latest changes from the SVN repository.

git-svn-dcommit-push: git svn dcommit && git push github $(git_main_branch):svntrunk
Commits to SVN and pushes to GitHub.
Integrates GitHub and SVN workflows by submitting changes to both platforms.
